wackpackr.core

Class LZWDictionary

  • java.lang.Object
    • wackpackr.core.LZWDictionary

  • public class LZWDictionary
extends Object
    Helper class that handles the dictionary needed in LZW compression and decompression.

    The dictionary works a bit differently depending whether encoding or decoding. When encoding, the dictionary needs to be able to tell quickly whether it contains a certain byte sequence or not, and what is its index. When decoding, the dictionary needs to be able to fetch byte sequences quickly by their index. Due to these differences, different data structures are used in each case.

    The first case is more complex. This implementation uses a prefix tree, combined with a trick that treats byte sequences as "prefix indexâ€”last byte" pairs (this takes advantage of the fact that when a new byte sequence is put to the dictionary, its prefix must have been put there earlier and thus has an index). With this trick, during the encoding process, the existence of byte sequences can be tested in near-constant time. Also, since a byte sequence of any length is stored simply as a pair of values, memory overhead is cut significantly.

    The decoding case is much simpler. The decoder only requests byte sequences by their index, and never asks for a sequence that would not have been stored prior. It should be immediately obvious that a standard array handles this just fine.

    Beside the dictionary, this class also keeps tabs on the bit size needed in encoding and decoding, because this is directly a function of the running dictionary size (that is, how many bits are needed to express the "highest" index in the dictionary at any given time). The bit size is checked and communicated back to the encoder/decoder after each insertion.

    The bit size used in encoding is capped, which sets a limit for dictionary size. Whenever the dictionary is full, it must be flushed to its initial state. Because this works differently whether encoding or decoding, monitoring dictionary size and resetting it is delegated to the encoder/decoder.

    Author:
    Juho Juurinen

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      LZWDictionary()
      Constructs and initialises a new dictionary for LZW encoding or decoding.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      ByteString get(int index)
      Returns the byte sequence associated with the given index.
      int get(int prefix, byte value)
      Returns the dictionary index associated with the byte sequence that is equal to "byte sequence associated with the given prefix index, appended with the given byte value".
      boolean isFull()
      Returns true if and only if the dictionary holds the maximum allowed number of elements.
      int put(ByteString bs)
      Inserts the given byte sequence to the dictionary, associating it with the next free index in line.
      int put(int prefix, byte value)
      Inserts to the dictionary a byte sequence that is equal to "byte sequence associated with the given prefix index, appended with the given byte value", and associates it with the next free index in line.
      void reset()
      Flushes the dictionary to its initial state, with the zero index reserved for the pseudo-EoF marker, and all possible one-byte sequences in the next 256 indexes, in ascending order.

        public boolean isFull()
        Returns true if and only if the dictionary holds the maximum allowed number of elements.
        Returns:

      • get

        public int get(int prefix,
               byte value)
        Returns the dictionary index associated with the byte sequence that is equal to "byte sequence associated with the given prefix index, appended with the given byte value". If no such sequence exists in the dictionary, a negative index is returned instead.
        Parameters:
        prefix - index of the byte sequence that forms the prefix part in the sought byte sequence
        value - the last byte in the sought byte sequence
        Returns:
        index of the sought byte sequence if it exists; -1 otherwise

      • put

        public int put(int prefix,
               byte value)
        Inserts to the dictionary a byte sequence that is equal to "byte sequence associated with the given prefix index, appended with the given byte value", and associates it with the next free index in line.
        Parameters:
        prefix - index of the byte sequence that forms the prefix part in the byte sequence to insert
        value - the last byte in the byte sequence to insert
        Returns:
        bit size needed in encoding after insertion

      • reset

        public final void reset()
        Flushes the dictionary to its initial state, with the zero index reserved for the pseudo-EoF marker, and all possible one-byte sequences in the next 256 indexes, in ascending order.
